title: Rudimentary, "functionless" first metapodials of Canis latrans: Variation and association in length with longer, functional metapodials
abstract: A tenet of evolutionary theory is that phenotypic variation of a trait is inversely related to the intensity of stabilizing selection pressure. Among homologous bones, such as metapodials, a rudimentary, "nonfunctional" bone is expected to be more variable in length than nonrudimentary bones. This study compares variation and association in length among metapodials using 277 adult skeletons of Canis latrans. Canis latrans has a short, "functionless" first metacarpal (mc1) and "rudimentary, vestigial" first metatarsal (mt1). Results show that among the 10 metapodials, mt1 has the highest variation in length; other metapodials do not differ significantly from one another in their variation. Correlation coefficients for length of mc1 and mt1 with their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 are significantly lower than coefficients for all other ipsilateral pairs. The correlation coefficient between left and right mt1 is significantly the lowest among all bilateral pairs of metapodials. Results are interpreted as follows. Mt1's high variation and low association in length are the outcome of less intense stabilizing selection pressure compared with other metapodials. The nonsignificant difference for variation in length between mc1 and metapodials 2-5 may be that mc1 is functional for development of a pollical dewclaw that helps restrain small prey.

body_text.text: A tenet of evolutionary theory is that phenotypic variation of a trait is inversely related to the intensity of stabilizing selection pressure (Schmalhausen 1949; Yablokov 1974; Fox 1975; Johnson 1976; Endler 1986; Mettler et al. 1988; Travis 1989 ). Among serially homologous structures, stabilizing selection is expected to be less intense on the intraspecific frequency distribution of size and shape of vestigial or rudimentary structures compared to their nonrudimentary, functional homologues; correspondingly, variance of the phenotypic frequency distribution is expected to be higher in vestigial, rudimentary structures. Simpson (1944:39) asserted that "it is so commonly true that degenerating structures are highly variable that this may be advanced as an empirical evolutionary generalization." "Degeneration" of a structure with attenuation or loss of function may occur when another structure can provide substitute, comparable functionality (e.g., lat-eral line system for prey detection in blind cavefish; Yoshizawa et al. 2014; Lloyd et al. 2018) . A second reason that a rudimentary structure may be highly variable is that it is undergoing rapid evolution for rudimentation by directional selection (Guthrie 1965) . However, there is not a consensus of this interpretation; Lande and Arnold (1983:1223) concluded that, "directional selection … decreases character variance" (also see Bader 1955; Johnson 1976) .

Canids have a short pollex and short first metacarpal (mc1), which have been characterized as vestigial and functionless, respectively (Munthe 1989; Castelló and Sillero-Zubiri 2018) . Canids do not have a hallux, but they retain a small first metatarsal (mt1), which has been described as rudimentary and vestigial (Flower 1885; Mivart 1890a; Munthe 1989; Tedford et al. 2009) . Wang and Tedford (2008) argued that shortening of the pollex and loss of the hallux are adaptations for cursorial locomotion among canids. In this study, I evaluate whether mc1 and mt1 in Canis latrans (Say, in James 1823; coyote) have higher variance and lower association in length, for both bilateral and ipsilateral pairs of metapodials, compared to their serially homologous, nonrudimentary metapodials. Figure 1 shows the metapodials of C. latrans. Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 tested the hypotheses that the metapodial of a rudimentary digit will have higher variation and lower association in length than metapodials of nonrudimentary digits among samples of 12 and 17 primate species, respectively. Results were consistent with both hypotheses for mc1 of the rudimentary or absent pollex of Ateles geoffroyi (Geoffroy's spider monkey) and Colobus guereza (mantled guereza) but not for mc2 of the rudimentary second digit of Perodicticus potto (potto). Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 argued that the proximate cause for high variation in length of mc1 in species with a rudimentary pollex is that differential allocation of mesenchyme among mc2-5 results in high variation in mesenchyme of the last metacarpal to form, which is mc1. The low association in length between mc1 and mc2-5 is a by-product of high variation in length of mc1. Tague (2002) suggested that P. potto's mc2 has lower variation and higher association in length than hypothesized because a functional pollex is important in this species' locomotion. Reallocation of mesenchyme from mc2 to mc3-5 would lead not only to high variation in length of mc2, but also disadvantageously to high variation in length of mc1. An alternative, but not mutually exclusive, proximate cause for the lower association in length between mc1 and mc2-5 among primates with a rudimentary pollex and for the higher association in length between mc2 and mc3-5 in a primate with a rudimentary second digit is that the genetic basis for digit identity and cellular proliferation differs between the first metapodials and metapodials 2-5 (see below).

The preponderance of carnivorans has five digits in the forefoot; exceptions include Lycaon in Canidae, Crocuta and Hyaena in Hyaenidae, and Bdeogale, Paracynictis, and Suricata in Herpestidae, which have four digits and are missing the pollex. The preponderance of carnivoran Families has five digits in the hindfoot; exceptions include Canidae, Felidae, and Hyaenidae, as well as a few genera in Herpestidae, including Bdeogale, Cynictis, Paracynictis, and Suricata, which have four digits and are missing the hallux (Owen 1866; Thomas 1882; Flower 1885; Mivart 1890a; Pocock 1914 Pocock , 1916 Taylor 1976 Taylor , 1986 Taylor , 1987 Rieger 1981; Mills 1982; Koehler and Richardson 1990; Nowak 1999; Gough-Palmer et al. 2008; van Staden 2014) . Table 1 and Supporting Information Table S1 present data from the literature on relative lengths of mc1 ([mc1/mc2]100%) and mt1 ([mt1/mt2]100%) among 13 species in Canidae and 19 species (plus one Zalophus species unspecified) in 10 other carnivoran Families. Table 1 shows that canids, felids, and hyaenids have relatively the shortest first metapodials compared with other carnivorans. In Canidae, relative length of mc1 ranges from 26% in Lycaon pictus (African wild dog) and Otocyon megalotis (bateared fox) to 48% in Nyctereutes procyonoides (raccoon dog). The four species in Felidae and one species in Hyaenidae have comparably short mc1, with relative length of mc1 ranging from 31% in Crocuta crocuta (spotted hyena) to 43% in Panthera onca (jaguar). The other species have relatively longer mc1, ranging from 62% in Cryptoprocta ferox (fossa) to 161% in Ommatophoca rossii (Ross seal). Among canids, relative length of mt1 ranges from 10% in Vulpes zerda (fennec fox) to 21% in N. procyonoides and Speothos venaticus (bush dog). Relative length of mt1 is 24% in the hyaenid Crocuta crocuta; no data were available for the felids. Among the other carnivorans, relative length of mt1 ranges from 69% in Pteronura brasiliensis (giant otter) to 146% in O. rossii. Canis latrans, which is the focal species of this study, has relatively short mc1 (45%) and mt1 (16%).

body_text.text: Canids are digitigrade, with a short pollex and no hallux. Castelló and Sillero-Zubiri (2018:12) characterized the pollex Table 1 . Length of first metacarpal relative to second metacarpal and of first metatarsal relative to second metatarsal (mc1, mc2, mt1, and mt2, respectively) among recent carnivorans based on published data † .

Relative length of mc1: (mc1/mc2)100% Table S1 for lengths of mc1, mc2, mt1, and mt2. as "vestigial," and Munthe (1989:86) asserted that the short mc1 is "functionless." Mt1 has been described as "minute," "rudiment(-ary)," and "vestigial" in canids in general (Owen 1866:510; Flower 1885:346; Mivart 1890a:xxi; Munthe 1989:90; Tedford et al. 2009:14) , and as "vestigial" in C. lupus (wolf; Argot 2010:94) and "short" in Chrysocyon brachyurus (maned wolf; Siqueira et al. 2017:576) . Wang and Tedford (2008:94) stated that, "All modern canids show loss of a functional first digit … (of) the hands and feet." Although the pollex is charac-terized as functionless in canids, it has two phalanges, which is the typical number of phalanges for terrestrial, pentadactyl mammals (Flower 1885; Mivart 1890a) . Canids have four digits of the hindfoot, with the exception of some large breeds of C. lupus familiaris (domestic dog) that may have one or two dewclaws on the hindfoot (e.g., Great Pyrenees, Newfoundlands, and St. Bernards [Alberch 1985] ); Lull (1904: 3) described the hindfoot dewclaw as "functionless … without connection with the rest of the (hindfoot)." Mivart (1890a) stated that in canids mt1 has a rudimentary phalanx, although this phalanx may be absent; with rare exception, the hallux has two phalanges (but see below, mt1 in C. latrans does not have an articular facet for a phalanx). The fossil record shows that extinct canids had comparably short mc1 but longer mt1 than extant canids. Canidae has three subfamilies-two are extinct (Borophaginae and Hesperocyoninae) and one is extant (Caninae). Wang (1993:19) summarized the phylogenetic and temporal relationships among these subfamilies: "The earliest …primitive canids were … hesperocyonines … in the Eocene to early Miocene…. This archaic group of canids was gradually replaced by borophagines in Mio-Pliocene, which was in turn replaced by canines (including all living canids) mainly in the Pliocene to Present." Based on metapodials from the same individual rather than from composite samples, relative length of mc1 in Hesperocyon (Hesperocyoninae) is 65%, which is outside the range of variation of living canids. In Borophaginae, relative length of mc1 overlaps the range of variation of living canids (Aelurodon, 46%, Tomarctus, 49%, and Archaeocyon, 60%), whereas relative length of mt1 is higher than that of living canids (Aelurodon, 48%, Tomarctus, 50%, and Archaeocyon, 61%; Munthe 1989:47, 63, her Tables 11 and 15; Wang 1993:16, his Table 1; Table 1 this study). This taxonomic assignment of fossil specimens follows Wang et al. (1999) , who assigned Strobodon (Munthe 1989) to be a junior synonym of Aelurodon and the Cormocyon specimens in Wang (1993) to Archaeocyon. Wang (1993:13) interpreted, "[t]he extremely reduced first digits in living canids … (as being) a derived condition within the subfamily Caninae…, (but that) reduction of metatarsus I and metacarpus I … has already become apparent in Hesperocyon." The hallux had one or more phalanges in Hesperocyon and the borophagines. Hesperocyon was plantigrade; borophagines were digitigrade (Munthe 1989; Wang 1993) . Wang (1993) stated that the first metapodials were functional in Hesperocyon and borophagines, although he did not explain their functionality. Munthe (1989:86) interpreted the forefoot of borophagines as showing "some indications … (that it) may have been manipulative"; she interpreted mt1 as not having contact with the ground, but she does not draw a conclusion about its functionality. In the evolution of Canidae, Hildebrand (1985:442, his Fig. 23-5) and Wang and Tedford (2008) argued that shortening of the pollex, loss of the hallux, elongation of metapodials 2-5, and digitigrade posture functionally lengthen the limbs to increase stride length, and are adaptations for cursorial locomotion.

Characterization of mc1 and mt1 in C. latrans as rudiments is not synonymous with them being functionless vestiges. Proximally, mc1 articulates with the first carpal and mc2; distally, it articulates with a phalanx (pers. obs.). In C. lupus familiaris, and inferentially in C. latrans, the following muscles attach to the pollex: abductor digiti I longus and extensor digiti I attach to mc1, and abductor digiti I brevis, adductor digiti I, and flexor digiti I brevis attach to the proximal phalanx. Collectively, these muscles abduct, adduct, extend, and flex the pollex, and abduct the forefoot (Hermanson et al. 2020) . Proximally, mt1 articulates with the first tarsal and mt2 in C. latrans; distally, there is no articular facet for a phalanx (pers. obs.). In C. lupus familiaris and other canids, and inferentially in C. latrans, the muscles fibularis longus and tibialis cranialis attach to mt1 (Lönnberg 1916; Piérard 1965; Hermanson et al. 2020) . These muscles flex the tarsus and evert and invert the hindfoot (Miller 1948; Munthe 1989; König and Liebich 2014; Hermanson et al. 2020 ). Furthermore, Smith et al. 2014 Smith et al. :2197 Smith et al. , 2202 argued that an "anatomically reduced" structure may be functionally important during a restricted period of time, but that functionality may be "transient." This interpretation is not inconsistent with the theoretical position that a rudimentary structure may be subject to less intense selection pressure compared to its nonrudimentary homologues. A rudimentary structure can be conjointly transiently functional during growth and development and highly variable in size in adulthood. As only metapodials of adults were used in this study (see below), the issue of transient functionality of the first metapodials was not addressed.

This study of C. latrans has three central issues, whether mc1 and mt1 differ from metapodials 2-5 in the following: (1) variance in length; (2) strength of association in length for bilateral pairs (e.g., correlation between left mc1 [lmc1] and right mc1 [rmc1]); and (3) strength of association in length of ipsilateral pairs (e.g., correlations between metacarpals on the same side of the forefoot-lmc1:lmc2, lmc1:lmc3, … lmc4:lmc5). Specific hypotheses tested are as follows: (1) mc1 and mt1 will have higher variance in length compared to metapodials 2-5, and (2) mc1 and mt1 will have lower correlations in length among both bilaterally paired metapodials and all combinations of ipsilateral metapodials. If mc1 or mt1 shows higher variance in length than metapodials 2-5, then additional evidence will be presented to interpret whether that difference is better explained by relaxation of stabilizing selection or directional selection. This study differs from Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 in a number of aspects. First, sample size for C. latrans in this study is 277 (see below), whereas sample size for individual species in Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 ranged from 18 to 41. The larger sample size in this study increases statistical power. Second, this study, but not Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 , addresses the issue of whether bilateral pairs of rudimentary and nonrudimentary metapodials differ in strength of association in length. Third, Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 evaluated species with one rudimentary metapodial, whereas this study evaluates one species with two rudimentary metapodials that differ in their magnitude of rudimentation (Table 1 ; see below). Wilson and Reeder (2005) were consulted for scientific and common names of species. Among species in Canidae, C. latrans was selected for study because of the anticipated large number of skeletons in museum collections in North America. Individuals were used in this study if the following four criteria were met:

(1) all five metacarpals or all five metatarsals of either the left or right sides were present and measurable; (2) all metapodial epiphyses were fused to the diaphyses; (3) there was no record that the individual had been held in captivity; and (4) there was no grossly observable pathology of the metapodials (e.g., healed fracture). One individual with unilateral brachymetatarsia of mt4 was included in the study because the etiology for the premature closure of the growth plate of the shortened bone was not discernible. As a focal issue of this study is difference among metapodials for variation in length, I decided not to exclude individuals simply because they were outliers in metapodial length. Based on these criteria, 277 individuals were studied, including 82 females, 111 males, and 84 individuals of sex not known. Museum records were consulted for assignation of species and sex and for locality. Locality information, at least to the administrative division of county, was available for all individuals.

Maximum length between the proximal and distal articular surfaces was measured for the metapodials; as mt1 does not have a distal articular surface (see above), maximum length was measured between the proximal articular surface and the most distal point on the shaft. Measurements were taken to the nearest 0.1 mm with a Mitutoyo dial caliper. Repeat measurements were taken on 240 metapodials from one day to two years after the original measurements. Measurement precision and percentage precision were computed as follows: precision = |original valuerepeat value|, and percentage precision = ([|original value-repeat value|]/original value)100%.

If traits are proportional in size to one another, Lewontin (1966) recommended taking logarithms of the measurements to enable direct comparison of their variances. Therefore, I used Levene's test to compare metapodials for variation in their logarithmically transformed (base 10) length. I followed Conover et al.'s (1981) recommendation of using the median rather than the mean as the statistic of central tendency in Levene's test. Levene's test compares samples for difference in their average median variation using Student's t test (Schultz 1983 (Schultz , 1985 : average
median variation = 1/n n i=1 |log X i -median(log X i )|. Levene's

test is robust and powerful among different sample distributions and sizes (Brown and Forsythe 1974; Van Valen 1978; Conover et al. 1981; Schultz 1983 Schultz , 1985 ; but see Martin and Games 1977) . Van Valen (1978:34) noted that, "Levene's test isn't quite a test of equality of variances. It is, strictly speaking, a joint test of all the even moments of the distributions: variance, kurtosis, etc. However, the effect of the variance predominates." More comprehensively, statistical tests used in this study were comparison of correlation coefficients with Fisher's transformation and using chi-square and Z values (Myers and Sirios 2006; Zar 2010) , Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Kruskal-Wallis test, Mann-Whitney test, Pearson's and Spearman's correlation coefficient analysis, Student's t test, and Welch's t' test. Statistical significance was set at p ≤ 0.05 (Q). I report results of multiple statistical tests, which increased the likelihood of Type I error. Therefore, this level of significance was adjusted using Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure (and this procedure is robust even when the multiple tests are not independent of one another; Benjamini and Yekutieli 2001). Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure is as follows. I performed 877 statistical tests ("ST", which are numbered consecutively in Results and Supporting Information). The adjusted critical level of significance for each test equals (i/m)Q, where i = rank of the p value for that test among all tests in consideration and m = number of STs. ST is significant if its unadjusted p is less than or equal to the adjusted critical p. I computed adjusted critical levels of significance for three sets of analyses: (1) measurement precision, (2) normality of frequency distributions, and (3) sexual dimorphism, variation, and correlation in length among metapodials. Although I present directional hypotheses with respect to mc1 and mt1 (see above), the preponderance of statistical tests was nondirectional. Therefore, two-tailed tests of significance were applied to all statistical tests. SPSS v26 (© IBM, Armonk, NY) was used for statistical analysis. Two online sources were also used for correlation coefficient analysis: (1) http://vassarstats.net for conversion of Pearson's r to Fisher's z, and for p value associated with Z score, and (2) http://onlinestatbook.com/calculators/fisher_z.html for conversion of the common Fisher's z to the common correlation coefficient.

Mean measurement precision for each of the 10 metapodials (with 12 left and 12 right bones remeasured for each metapodial) ranged from 0.004 mm (mc1, mc4, and mt2-4) to 0.121 mm (mt5); mean percentage precision for each metapodial ranged from 99.7 (mt1) to > 99.9% (mc1-5 and mt2-4). For all 240 metapodials combined, mean measurement precision was 0.02 mm, with extreme values of 0.0 and 0.5 mm, and mean percentage precision was >99.9%, with extreme values of 97.9 and 100.0% (Table 2) . The first issue is whether measurement precision and percentage precision differ among the metapodials. The first analysis tests whether the frequency distributions of measurement precision and percentage precision for all metapodials combined differ significantly from normality, and results show a significant difference for both distributions (ST 1 and 2, p < 0.001, n = 240, Kruskal-Wallis test). The second analysis determines which metapodial(s) differs from others in the magnitude of measurement precision and percentage precision. Results show that measurement precision and percentage precision are significantly the lowest for mt5, and the other nine metapodials do not differ significantly from one another in their measurement precision and percentage precision (Mann-Whitney test, ST 3-92, Supporting Information Table S2 ).

As mc1 and mt1 are described alternatively as functionless, rudimentary, short, and vestigial in canids (see above), mc1 and mt1 in C. latrans are hypothesized to be more variable in length than metapodials 2-5. This expected higher variation suggests that the frequency distributions for the samples of mc1 and mt1 might not be normally distributed. The second issue is to determine whether parametric or nonparametric tests are appropriate for statistical analyses, and the third analysis evaluates whether the frequency distributions of mc1, mt1, and metapodials 2-5 differ significantly from normality. The data sets evaluated are as follows:

(1) length of left and right metapodials for females, males, and all individuals combined, and (2) average median variation in log length of left and right metapodials for females and males. Tague (1997 Tague ( , 2002 reported a significant, positive correlation between magnitude of sexual dimorphism and average median variation among primates. Therefore, the samples of females and males of C. latrans were evaluated separately for length and average median variation in log length of metapodials because of expected sexual dimorphism in skeletal size (Kennedy et al. 2003 ; see below). The sample of all individuals (i.e., females, males, and sex not known) was evaluated for length of metapodials because this combined sample was used in correlational analyses. Results show that the distribution of length of rmt1 for the sample of all individuals differs significantly from normality (ST 148, unadjusted p < 0.001, Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Supporting Information Table S3 ). Although none of the other distributions differs significantly from normality (ST 93-147, 149-192, Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Supporting Information Table S3 ), the distribution of length of lmt1 for the sample of all individuals closely approaches significance (ST 143, unadjusted p = 0.002, Supporting Information Table S3 ). Because the distributions of right and left mt1 for the sample of all individuals differ significantly or closely approach differing significantly from normality, lengths of metapodials for the sample of all individuals were then log transformed and the frequency distributions reevaluated for deviation from normality. Results of this reevaluation show that none of the distributions of log length of metapodials for the sample of all individuals differs significantly from normality. Therefore, parametric tests were used in all subsequent statistical analyses for sexual dimorphism in metapodial length, difference among metapodials in average median variation of log length, and correlational analysis of log length (but see Dual Consideration of Type I and Type II Errors).

The third issue is to evaluate the hypothesis that mc1 and mt1 will have higher variance in length (i.e., higher average median variation in log length) compared to metapodials 2-5. The fourth analysis determines whether females and males are different from one another in metapodial length and, if not, can be combined into a single sample for analysis of average median variation in log length. Results show that the sexes do not differ significantly for lengths of lmt1 and rmt1, but males have significantly higher mean values than females for lengths of the other 18 metapodials (ST 193-212, Student's t test, Table 3, Supporting Information  Table S4 ). Among the 18 metapodials for which males are significantly larger than females, the percentage dimorphism ranges from 3.8% for lmc1 to 5.4% for lmt2 (Table 3) .

As the sexes differ significantly in length for 18 of 20 metapodials, the fifth analysis evaluates females and males separately for difference among metapodials in the average median variation of log length. Results for both females and males show that there is a significant difference among the 20 metapodials in their average median variation (ST 213 and 214, unadjusted p < 0.001, Welch's t' test, Supporting Information Table S4 ). The sixth analysis determines which metapodial(s) differs significantly from others in the average median variation by analyzing all pairwise comparisons among metapodials in females and males. Results in both females and males show the following: (1) lmt1 and rmt1 are not significantly different from one another in their average median variations, but lmt1 and rmt1 have significantly higher average median variations than all other metapodials, and (2) all other metapodials (left and right mc1-5 and mt2-5) are not significantly different from one another in their average median variations (ST 215-604, Student's t test, Table 4 , Supporting Information Table S4 ).

The fourth issue is to evaluate the hypothesis that the strength of association in log length between bilaterally paired metapodials (e.g., lmc1:rmc1, lmc2:rmc2, and so forth) will be lower for mc1 and mt1 among the 10 pairs of metapodials. The seventh analysis uses the sample of all individuals (females, males, and sex not known) to compute the correlation coefficient for each bilateral pair of metapodials. Results show that the correlation coefficients range from 0.929 for mt1 to 0.996 for mc2 and mt2; all correlation coefficients are significantly different from zero (ST 595-604, Table 5 , Supporting Information Table S4 ). The eighth analysis compares the correlation coefficients among the Table 4 . 10 bilateral pairs of metapodials, and results show a significant difference in their magnitude (ST 605, unadjusted p < 0.001, chi-square with Fisher's transformation, Supporting Information Table S4 ). The ninth analysis determines which correlation(s) among the 10 bilateral pairs of metapodials is significantly different from the others by analyzing all pairwise comparisons of the correlation coefficients. Results are as follows: (1) mt1 has significantly the lowest correlation coefficient among the 10 metapodials (r = 0.929); (2) mc1 and mt4 are nonsignificantly different in their correlation coefficients (r = 0.975 and 0.961, respectively), but their correlation coefficients are significantly lower than those for mc2-5, mt2-3, and mt5; (3) mc3 has a significantly lower correlation coefficient (0.993) than mc2 and mt2 (0.996); and (4) all other pairwise comparisons are nonsignificant (ST 606-650, Table 6 , Supporting Information Table S4 ). The common correlation coefficient for mc1 and mt4 is 0.970, and the common correlation coefficient for mc2, mc4-5, mt2-3, and mt5 is 0.995.

The fifth issue is to determine the strength of association among metapodials in their log lengths within the forefoot and hindfoot (e.g., lmc1:lmc2, lmc1:lmc3, … lmc4:lmc5), with an hypothesis that mc1 and mt1 will have lower correlations with their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 than metapodials 2-5 have with one another. Table 7 presents correlation coefficients between the log lengths of all pairs of ipsilateral metapodials in the forefoot and hindfoot, and the 10th analysis shows that all correlation coefficients are significantly different from zero (ST 651-690, unadjusted p < 0.001, Supporting Information Table S4 ). The 11th analysis compares the magnitude of the 10 correlation coefficients for each forefoot and hindfoot, and results show a significant difference among the coefficients for both forefeet and hindfeet (ST 691-694, unadjusted p < 0.001, chi-square with Fisher's transformation, Supporting Information Table S4 ). The 12th analysis uses pairwise comparison among the correlation coefficients for each forefoot and hindfoot to identify which coefficient(s) differs significantly from the others. Results are as follows: (1) correlation coefficients of lmc1 with lmc2-5 do not differ significantly from one another, nor do coefficients of rmc1 with rmc2-5, lmt1 with lmt2-5, and rmt1 with rmt2-5, and (2) the correlation coefficient between metapodials 3 and 4 is significantly higher than all other coefficients for left and right metacarpals and right metatarsals (ST 695-874, Z value with Fisher's transformation, Table 8 , Supporting Information Table S4 ). Based on these results, the 13th analysis evaluates whether a common correlation coefficient can be computed for each of the following sets of metapodials: (1) left and right mc1 with mc2-5, (2) left and right mt1 with mt2-5, and (3) left and right mc3 with mc4. Results show no significant difference among the correlation coefficients for these three sets of metapodials (ST 875-877, Supporting Information Table S4 ), and the common correlation coefficients are 0.759 for lmc1 with lmc2-5 and rmc1 with rmc2-5, 0.345 for lmt1 with lmt2-5 and rmt1 with rmt2-5, and 0.991 for left and right mc3:mc4 (Table 7) . The correlation coefficients for the other combinations of metapodials (i.e., 2:3, 2:4, 2:5, 3:5, and 4:5) range from 0.961 to 0.982 for left metacarpals, from 0.964 to 0.981 for right metacarpals, from 0.947 to 0.984 for left metatarsals, and from 0.973 to 0.981 for right metatarsals.
body_text.section: ASSOCIATION IN LENGTH AMONG IPSILATERAL METAPODIALS IN FOREFOOT AND HINDFOOT

body_text.text: I report results of 877 statistical tests, and I used Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) Table S3 ). If the distributions of these 15 samples are con-sidered to be meaningfully different from normality and if nonparametric tests had been used for all analyses involving these 15 samples rather than parametric tests (e.g., Kruskal-Wallis test, Mann-Whitney test, and Spearman's correlation coefficient analysis), then only two of the 685 results comparing metapodials for sexual dimorphism in length and for variation and association in log length would differ from those previously reported . Using parametric tests, average median variation in log length of lmc1 is not significantly different from that of lmt5 in females (ST 228), and the correlation coefficient between lengths of left and right mc1 is significantly higher than that of left and right mt1 (ST 610). However, use of nonparametric tests shows that lmc1 has a significantly higher average median variation than lmt5 in females, and the correlation coefficients for the bilateral pairs of mc1 and mt1 are not significantly different from one another (nonparametric results not reported). Furthermore, nine of the 685 results using parametric tests approach significance (i.e., adjusted critical p < unadjusted p ≤ 0.05, ST 203, 227, 228 [discussed above], 422, 502, 777, 784, 818, and 816, Supporting Information Table S4 ). For these STs, if the unadjusted p is accepted as being meaningfully significant, then the results would be interpreted as follows: (1) males > females for length of lmt1 (ST 203); (2) average median variation in log length of lmc1 > lmt4 in females, and lmc1 > rmt4 and rmc1 > rmt4 in males (ST 227, 422, and 502, respectively), and (3) four assessments would change concerning a difference of correlation coefficients between ipsilateral pairs of metapodials 2-5 (ST 777, 784, 816, and 818; e.g., assessment of correlation coefficients between rmc2:rmc4 and rmc3:rmc5 would change from being not significantly different to the former coefficient being meaningfully higher than the latter; ST 777, Table 7, Supporting  Information Table S4 ). Table 8 . Comparison of correlation coefficients of log lengths among all pairs of ipsilateral metapodials in forefoot and hindfoot of Canis latrans (Table 7) ; sample is of females, males, and individuals of sex not known; statistical significance based on unadjusted p ≤ adjusted critical p (statistical tests 695-874, Table 7, Supporting Information Table S4) † .
body_text.section: DUAL CONSIDERATION OF TYPE I AND TYPE II ERRORS

body_text.text: Metapodials lmc1:lmc2 lmc1:lmc3 lmc1:lmc4 lmc1:lmc5 lmc2:lmc3 lmc2:lmc4 lmc2:lmc5 lmc3:lmc4 lmc3:lmc5

Living canids are digitigrade in posture and cursorial in locomotion. Hildebrand (1952:234) described C. latrans as a "good runner." Lull (1904) , Hildebrand (1985) , Polly (2007) , and Wang and Tedford (2008) stated that reduction in length of the pollex and loss of the hallux are cursorial adaptations in canids. Although the preponderance of canids has a pollical dewclaw, Lull (1904: 3) described the forefoot as "functionally tetradactyly," and Wang and Tedford (2008) stated that the pollex is not functional in modern canids. Canis latrans is similar to other canids in having relatively short mc1 and mt1 (length of mc1 relative to mc2, and mt1 relative to mt2, are 35% and 13%, respectively, using means of left and right metapodials for all individuals, Table 3 ; compare with relative lengths of mc1 and mt1 for other canids, Table 1 ).

Mc1 is characterized as functionless (Munthe 1989 ) and mt1 as minute, rudimentary, and vestigial (Owen 1866; Flower 1885; Mivart 1890a; Munthe 1989; Tedford et al. 2009) in canids. I addressed three hypotheses in this study, that mc1 and mt1 will: (1) have higher variation in length than metapodials 2-5; (2) show lower correlation in length between the left and right bones compared to the correlations between bilateral pairs of metapodials 2-5; and (3) show lower correlation in length with their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 than metapodials 2-5 do with one another. There are few differences in results between methods to limit Type I and Type II errors, and biological reality is probably somewhere in-between the interpretation of results based on one or the other method. For mt1, results are consistent with the three hypotheses: mt1 is highly variable in log length, has a lower association in log length with its ipsilateral metatarsals compared to all other pairings of mt2-5, has a lower association in log length between its bilateral pair of bones (i.e., left and right mt1) compared at least to the bilateral pairs of metapodials 2-5, but the correlation coefficient in log length between the bilateral pair of left and right mt1 is, nevertheless, high. For mc1, results are consistent with the hypothesis about correlation in log length among ipsilateral metapodials, but results are not consistent with the hypotheses about variation in log length and correlation in log length of bilateral pairs. The biologically relevant understanding of results for mc1 is that variation in log length of mc1 generally is not different from that of metapodials 2-5, but log length of mc1 has a low association with log lengths of mc2-5. Results are explained as follows.

Mt1 is significantly more variable in length compared to other metapodials because it is a rudiment: (1) length of mt1 is 13% that of mt2; (2) mt1 does not articulate with a phalanx and, correspondingly, there is no hallux; and (3) mt1 is not weight bearing. A rudimentary structure may be highly variable in length for the following reasons: (1) intensity of stabilizing selection pressure on its length is relaxed (Schmalhausen 1949; Yablokov 1974; Fox 1975; Johnson 1976; Endler 1986; Mettler et al. 1988; Travis 1989) ; (2) it is subject to directional selection for rudimentation (Guthrie 1965) ; or (3) its high variation is an epiphenomenon of its short length (Rohlf et al. 1983; Jouffroy et al. 1993 ). There are three lines of evidence suggesting that metapodial length among extant canids is not under directional selection. First, Hildebrand (1952) argued that extant canids are not currently undergoing evolution of metapodial length to enhance cursorial adaptation, based on comparative lengths of metapodials 2-5. Second, C. chihliensis, which appears "to be a stem group in the Lupus clade" (Tedford et al. 2009:5) and dated to >1.36 Ma, had a "vestigial" mt1 (Tong et al. 2012:352 , also see their Fig. 9B4 ). Third, relative mc1 length in extant C. lupus is 33%, a value little different from 37% in C. chihliensis and 31% in C. lupus dated to >43,000 B.P. (Table 1 ; Tong et al. 2012; Salari et al. 2017) . This evidence fails to support a generalization that mc1 or mt1 in extant canids is undergoing directional selection for rudimentation.

An explanation that high variation in length of mt1 is an epiphenomenon of its short length is also not likely correct. Rohlf et al. (1983) and Jouffroy et al. (1993) argued that measurement precision may be lower for a shorter bone than for a longer bone, and this lower measurement precision inflates the variance of the shorter bone. Rohlf et al. (1983:195) concluded that, "[t]he way to avoid this problem is … to measure the small features with the same relative level of precision as that used on the larger structures." However, measurement precision and percentage precision in this study are high, and there is no significant difference in measurement precision and percentage precision among mc1-5 and mt1-4. Measurement precision for mt5 is significantly lower than that for the other nine metapodials, and the reason may be that length between the proximal and distal facets was simply a measurement of maximum length of the bone for mc1-5 and mt1-4 (there is no distal facet on mt1, see above), whereas measurement of maximum length between proximal and distal facets of mt5 necessitated multiple attempts to avoid the nonarticular tubercle on the proximal, lateral side of that bone. Therefore, the significantly higher variation in length of mt1 compared to the other nine metapodials in C. latrans is not likely an artifact of its rudimentary length. As directional selection and measurement imprecision fail to explain high variation in length of mt1, the inference is that length of mt1 in C. latrans is subject to less intense stabilizing selection pressure compared to lengths of the other metapodials.

Although mc1 has been characterized as "functionless" in canids (Munthe 1989:86) , the nonsignificant difference between mc1 and metapodials 2-5 for variation in their lengths implies that the intensity of stabilizing selection on their lengths is comparable. A corollary is that mc1 may not be functionless.

Mc1 articulates with a phalanx, and mc1 is part of a short pollex that terminates with a dewclaw. The pollex is also short and terminates with a dewclaw in felids (see relative length of mc1 in felids, Table 1 ; see figures in Pocock 1917) . Two species of felids, Acinonyx jubatus (cheetah) and Panthera pardus (leopard), use the pollical dewclaw in predation (Burton 1950; Kirberger et al. 2000; Stein and Hayssen 2013) . Kirberger et al. (2000:175) reported that functionality of the dewclaw in A. jubatus is related principally to a "well developed" sesamoid in the tendon of abductor digiti I longus and paired sesamoids at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Canis lupus familiaris, and inferentially C. latrans, similarly has a sesamoid in the tendon of abductor digiti I longus, but C. lupus familiaris differs from A. jubatus in having only one sesamoid at the metacarpophalangeal joint (Hermanson et al. 2020) . Canis latrans may be subject to selection for mc1 (and, correspondingly, selection for the pollex) to be long enough to have a dewclaw that could be used to restrain prey. Canis latrans preys on small mammals, such as leporids and rodents, although its diet is diverse (Sperry 1933; Bond 1939; Murie O. 1935 Murie O. , 1945 Murie A. 1951; Fichter et al. 1955; Korschgen 1957; Gier 1968; Springer and Smith 1981) . Canis latrans sometimes pounces on its smaller prey, stabbing and restraining its quarry with its forefeet (Murie 1940; Fox 1969; Wells and Bekoff 1982) . Perhaps as C. latrans grapples with prey prior to delivering the killing bite, the prey may be restrained, in part, by being snagged on the dewclaw. I find no citational reference to C. latrans' use of the dewclaw in this manner, but this supposition could explain retention of the dewclaw and the nonsignificant difference between mc1 and metapodials 2-5 in their variation in length.

There may be (at least) two proximate causes, not mutually exclusive of one another, for the low correlation in length between the first metapodials and their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5. First, the genetic contributions to digit development differ between the first digit and digits 2-5. In the developing autopod of mice, Hoxd-10, , and shh (sonic hedgehog) are expressed in digits 2-5, whereas among these genes only Hoxa-13 and Hoxd-13 are expressed in digit 1 (Fromental-Ramain et al. 1996; Montavon et al. 2008; Wagner and Vargas 2008; Tickle and Barker 2013) . This genetic difference may contribute to the low correlation in length between metapodial 1 and its ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 and the high correlation in length among ipsilateral metapodials 2-5. However, this early developmental difference between digits 1 and digits 2-5 cannot explain fully the correlational results seen in this study unless similar results are seen among pentadactyl mammals in general. Gulo gulo (wolverine), however, does not conform with this expectation.

Gulo gulo has relative lengths of mc1 and mt1 of 73% and 79%, respectively (Table 1) . Based on data in Döppes (2001:89-90, her Tables 16 and 17) , the mean correlation coefficients for the first metapodial with ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 are 0.944 for mc1 and 0.866 for mt1, which are about the same as or higher than the mean correlation coefficients among ipsilateral metapodials 2-5, which are 0.963 for mc2-5 and 0.776 for mt2-5. A second proximate cause for the low correlation in length of the first metapodial with metapodials 2-5 in C. latrans may be a difference in the tempo and duration of growth among metapodials. Mt1 develops from a single center of ossification (in C. lupus familiaris, and inferentially in C. latrans), whereas mt2-5 develop from two centers of ossification-diaphysis and distal epiphysis (in C. lupus familaris; Hare 1960 Hare , 1961 pers. obs. for mt2-5 in C. latrans) . This difference in ossification may contribute to different growth trajectories between mt1 and mt2-5. Reno et al. (2006) reasoned that the nonepiphyseal end of a metapodial ossifies in a manner similar to that of a bone with a single center of ossification. In mice, Reno et al. (2006) documented that chondrocytes at the nonepiphyseal end of the metapodial are less organized in orientation and slower in proliferation than those at the epiphyseal end. Humans are similar in this difference; humans also show that the nonepiphyseal end completes ossification before the epiphyseal end (Ogden et al. 1994) . Therefore, absence of a growth plate for mt1 in C. lupus familiaris, and inferentially in C. latrans, implies a potential difference between mt1 and mt2-5 in tempo and duration of growth. Mc1 may also have a different tempo and duration of growth than mc2-5. Although all metacarpals develop from two centers of ossification, the epiphysis for mc1 is proximal to the diaphysis, whereas the epiphysis for mc2-5 is distal to the diaphysis (Hare 1959 (Hare , 1960 (Hare , 1961 . This difference may too lead to different growth trajectories between mc1 and mc2-5. In C. lupus familiaris, and inferentially in C. latrans, ossification of the proximal epiphysis of mc1 begins later than ossification of the distal epiphyses of mc2-5 (Hare 1959 (Hare , 1961 Chapman 1965; Coulson and Lewis 2008) . Reports on age at closure of the proximal and distal epiphyseal growth plates of mc1 and mc2-5, respectively, in C. lupus familiaris differ; Chapman (1965) reported that the proximal growth plate of mc1 closes at an earlier age than the distal growth plates of mc2-5, whereas Hare (1959 Hare ( , 1960 , Ticer (1984) , and Coulson and Lewis (2008) reported that the growth plates for mc1 and mc2-5 close at the same age.

body_text.text: The ultimate cause for the low correlation in length between the first metapodials and their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5 is that the first metapodials are functionally and partly genetically autonomous from metapodials 2-5. Metapodials 2-5 are weight bearing, and their lengths are functionally and genetically "integrated" with one another (Campbell 2009) . In contrast, the first metapodials are not weight bearing, and the genetic basis for their identity differs from that of metapodials 2-5 (see above). Finally, length of the rudimentary mt1 may have little or no functional significance, whereas length of mc1 is important for development of a pollical dewclaw that may contribute to C. latrans' predatory success. This difference in (proposed) functionality between mc1 and mt1 may explain their difference in correlation coefficients with their ipsilateral metapodials 2-5. Crespi and Vanderkist (1997) argued that vestigial traits, because of inferred absence of functionality, would show high level of fluctuating asymmetry. Mt1 in C. latrans is rudimentary in length and likely has limited to no functionality (see above). Although I did not compute fluctuating asymmetry for bilateral pairs of metapodials, mt1 has significantly the lowest correlation coefficient (0.929) between left and right bones among the 10 bilateral pairs of metapodials (although see Dual Consideration of Type I and Type II Errors; nonparametric analysis shows a nonsignificant difference between correlation coefficients of bilateral pairs of mc1 and mt1). Bilateral pairs of mc1 and mt4 are not significantly different from one another in their correlation coefficients (0.975 and 0.961, respectively), but their correlation coefficients are significantly lower than those for the other seven bilateral pairs of metapodials. The significantly lower correlation coefficient for mt4 compared to mc2-5, mt2-3, and mt5 is an artifact of brachymetatarsia in one individual. In this individual, lmt4 is 12.3 mm shorter than rmt4 (65.4 vs. 77.7 mm, respectively [Supporting Information Table S5 ]; among the 1,520 bilateral pairs of metapodials [n = 170 for each bilateral pair of metacarpals and n = 134 for each bilateral pair of metatarsals, Table 5 ], the penultimate and antepenultimate absolute differences between left and right bones of a bilateral pair are 6.6 and 2.7 mm, respectively, both for mt1 [Supporting Information Table  S5] ). If the individual with brachymetatarsia is not included in computation of the correlation coefficient between log lengths of left and right mt4, then the correlation coefficient for the bilateral pair of mt4 is 0.996. The magnitude of this correlation coefficient is comparable to those of the other metapodials 2-5, which range from 0.993 to 0.996 (Table 5) . Therefore, with exclusion of the individual with brachymetatarsia, the correlation coefficients for the bilateral pairs of the short mc1 (0.975) and rudimentary mt1 (0.929) are lower than those for metapodials 2-5. These results are consistent with the interpretation that the level of functional integration in length is higher for the weight bearing metapodials 2-5 than for the nonweight bearing first metapodials. Interestingly, the high correlation coefficient between left and right mt1 suggests that absent unilateral pathology, directional asymmetry, or antisymmetry, a rudimentary structure may be expected to show high association in length as a bilateral pair. Understanding the proximate causes(s) of left-right symmetry in bone length is an active area of research. Symmetry in limb bud development involves active suppression of asymmetrical influencers, and symmetry in postnatal growth involves communication between contralateral bones (Grimes 2019) . Zhang et al. (2017) documented a progression toward symmetry in the developing limb bud. The level of sonic hedgehog protein, which influences patterning and growth of the limb bud, differs between left and right limb buds of the same individual early in development, but that difference is reduced soon thereafter. Zhang et al. (2017) do not identify the cause(s) for the initial difference and later equilibration in protein levels.

Variation in length of mc1, mt1, and metapodials 2-5 in C. latrans was evaluated through the theoretical perspective that a rudimentary, vestigial structure will be highly variable in length because of less intense stabilizing selection pressure on the functionless rudiment's phenotypic frequency distribution compared with that of its functional homologues. Results for the rudimentary mt1, but not for the short mc1, are in accord with theoretical expectation. The inference is that lengths of mc1 and metapodials 2-5 may be subject to a comparable level of selection pressure. Selection on length of metacarpals 2-5 is associated with their functions in weight bearing and increasing stride length. Neither mc1 nor mt1 is weight bearing. Whereas a hallux is absent, a pollex with a dewclaw is present. Selection on mc1's length is likely associated with development of a dewclaw that may contribute to C. latrans' predatory success. This study shows that analysis of variation in size of a previously described "functionless" trait may lead to reconsideration of its "functionality." AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS R.G.T. contributed 100% to the design, data collection, analysis, interpretation, and writing of the manuscript.
